comments:
Files with the extension .class cannot be saved in Eclipse. 
Legitimate uses of editing .class files inlcude:
- .class files as source code (text) files in other languages, e.g. PHP
- being able to pick apart .class files if you've got a .jar you've repackaged in Eclipse is kinda handy
- ...

The problem:
When you try to save a edited .class file, you get a "Save failed: null" error, easy to reproduce.

Steps to reproduce:
1. install eclipse sdk (JDT must be included)
2. create a text file with the extension .class
3. open the test.class file in Eclipse, change a few characters
4. Hit save (Ctrl+S)
--> You get the error and the file is not saved.

The problem is that plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.1.2 associates the .class extension with it and locks this association. 

Related bugs:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=93956
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=105579

I have explained the issue here:
http://codex.gallery2.org/index.php/Gallery2:Eclipse_Tutorial#Installation_and_Configuration

And a hack to get it working for PHP is here:
http://codex.gallery2.org/index.php/Gallery2:Eclipse_Tutorial#Solving_the_Problem_with_Saving_.class_Files

Thanks for your time :)

BTW: I'm not using Version 3.1 as indicated in the bug summary, I'm using Eclipse SDK 3.1.2, but that's not an option in the list above.
Also, I'm using PHPeclipse 1.1.7, but that doesn't matter since I can't save .class files whether or not PHPeclipse is installed.

The fact that JDT Core 'locks' the .class file extension is not the problem here. It seems that the regular text editor is misbehaving. Here is the stack trace from  that is logged:

Can reproduce on I20060131-1200.
Looks like bug 100032 which has been marked fixed.

Note: the API of IContentTypeMatcher.getDescriptionFor(Reader, String, QualifiedName[]) neither specs that passing a reader for binary types is invalid nor does it spec that an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.

It is a duplicate of bug 100032, indeed.

Daniel, after that bug was fixed, the UnsupportedOperationException is now only thrown if the client retrieves a binary content type (whose content describer does not implement ITextContentDescriber) and calls:

IContentType#getDescriptionFor(Reader, QualifiedName[])

The implementation of the API you mentioned will silently ignore those content types, so we are fine.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 100032 ***
